meanings.def: to take liquid, air, etc. into your mouth by using the muscles of your lips
examples: to suck the juice from an orange
She was noisily sucking up milk through a straw.
He sucked the blood from a cut on his finger.

meanings.def: to keep something in your mouth and pull on it with your lips and tongue
examples: suck at/on something The baby sucked at its mother's breast.
He sucked at the wound on his hand.
suck something She sucked a mint.

meanings.def: to take liquid, air, etc. out of something
examples: suck something + adv./prep. The pump sucks air out through the valve.
suck something + adj. Greenfly can literally suck a plant dry.
The machine sucks up mud and stones from the bottom of the pond.

meanings.def: to pull somebody/something with great force in a particular direction
examples: The canoe was sucked down into the whirlpool.
The mud had sucked him in up to his waist.

meanings.def: used to say that something is very bad
to get from somebody/something all the money, help, information, etc. they have, usually giving nothing in return
examples: By earning millions from racing and giving pennies back, the bookmakers are sucking the sport dry.

meanings.def: used to say that the only way to know if something is suitable is to try it
to accept something bad and deal with it well, controlling your emotions
to tell or show somebody how to do something that they can already do well, and probably better than you can
